abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Community Action Project
            in Support of the First Phase of the Community Action
            Program Project for Niger were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, Global Environmental Objective (GEO) outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: bottom-up development based on a
            community-driven development (CDD) approach can be achieved
            in a context like Niger if supervision is careful and
            benefits from a dedicated team. The process is particularly
            difficult if public services and institutions outside the
            main cities are limited or non-existent (as was the case in
            Niger). For a new program in such a challenging field as
            community-driven development, it is necessary to have modest
            expectations at the beginning. In Niger, the Community
            Action Program had an outreach target of 20 percent of the
            communes (districts) for the first four years. For an
            emergency program the intended outcome is that the effects
            of the crisis are minimized and recovery from the disaster
            can start. For an avian flu attack the outcome would be that
            information is quickly shared with responsible authorities
            and that deaths are avoided or at least minimized. Thus the
            original outcome indicators in the Project Paper were
            correctly conceived when they largely concentrated on the
            reaction and reporting times by the local population and
            then by the authorities responsible for surveillance and treatment.
